adventure_overview: When you go “into the wild,” you will begin to learn about some of the mammals, birds, reptiles, amphibians, and insects that live with us day and night and how they contribute to the world in which we live. Prior to any activity, use Scouting America’s SAFE Checklist to ensure the safety of all those involved. All participants in official Scouting America activities should become familiar with the Guide to Safe Scouting and applicable program literature or manuals.

requirements.text: Visit a place with a variety of wild animals.  Select one of the animals and observe its behavior.  Use your selected animal to complete the remaining requirements.

activities.name: On the Trail
activities.description: Walk along a trail  and search for the perfect animal.

activities.name: Wilderness Preserve
activities.description: Visit a  wildlife park  and search for the perfect animal.

activities.name: Zoo Visit
activities.description: Visit a zoo and search for the perfect animal.

requirements.text: Create a model of your animal’s ecosystem.

activities.name: Claymation
activities.description: Cub Scouts create their animal’s ecosystem using clay.

activities.name: Life in a Shoebox
activities.description: Cub Scouts create a diorama showing their animal’s ecosystem.

requirements.text: Investigate how your animal coexists with other animals  in the wild.

activities.name: Web of Life
activities.description: Cub Scouts play a game to learn the web of life.

requirements.text: Describe how humans interact with your chosen animal’s ecosystem.

activities.name: Human Interaction
activities.description: Cub Scouts add human interaction to their animal ecosystem.

requirements.text: Discover how wildlife management benefits your animal.

activities.name: Wildlife Speaker
activities.description: Invite a wildlife expert to speak at a den meeting.
